37701647.review:
One of the best shmups you will find here on Steam, and also a pretty accessible CAVE-like bullet hell for newcomers to the genre. Some of its main characteristics are the lock-on missiles and the "break mode", which awards you more points and you also deal a hell of a lot of damage. It features a handful of modes, like "BOOST mode", which changes difficulty depending on your skill, and even a "time attack" mode if you're into that. Now, if NOVICE mode can be easily beat by danmaku veterans, the original ARCADE mode will definitely take some hours to master, and even more time while trying to beat the UNLIMITED mode (although credits are infinite, thankfully).

In summary, adjustable difficulty and rewarding gameplay. Get it now if you're interested in getting into the danmaku genre or you just want one enjoyable shoot 'em up that does everything right.

37410656.review:
[h1]シューティング初心者から上級者まで楽しめる[/h1]
シューターであれば必ず持っていると思っていいほどの良作であり、萌え要素一切なしの硬派シューティング。

爽快感が売りの作品で、詳しいことは紹介動画とスクリーンショットを見ればすぐにわかることだろう。
また本ゲームには、初心者でも遊べるノービスモードがあり、弾速や弾量が減った状態で遊ぶことができる。シューティングが苦手な私でも楽しむことが出来た。

もうひとつ重要なのは"値段"だ。xbox360で発売されているようなシューティング作品は、他ジャンルと同等の価格設定になっていて手を伸ばしづらい。スマホでは無料のシューティングゲームもあるが、それらでは物足りないと思っている人がいることだろう。

価格設定とクオリティー。ともに最適であるのがこのゲームだ。

セールで価格が安くなったときに、DLCと一緒に買ってしまえば……
いとも簡単に、シューティングの世界にのめり込むことができる。

Played 1 full playthrough of novice. I have one major problem with this game: The screen is too cluttered to see the bullets. the visual noise is just so crowded that it's difficult to see enemy fire. I think the developer can do a few things to fix this in a future game; (beniog a 2014 release I highly doubt this advice will affect a future patch)

suggestions

1. tone down the color pallete of all but essential graphics. so bring the saturation of everything down by 50%, and leave bullets, the player, and target reticles in full color. that would bring much more focus to the gameplay despite the clutter.

2. remove all colors used for bullets, this way an exclusive set of colors can be used to recognize bullets. if you removed all the bright blue and red from the game except for the bullets, you'd make them stand out much better.

34489072.review:
If you've ever wondered why arcade halls still make a profit in Japan, this game is the answer: pure quality, and then a million explosions and flashing bonus popups on top to make it feel even cooler. Crimzon Clover World Ignition is basically an arcade port, but it has a much-needed easy mode that makes enemies shoot a lot less: I've not even beat the first stage on Arcade difficulty yet, and the Novice mode definitely isn't a slouch either. The game is fairly short, but if you want to beat it without using continues, you'll easily get a few hours of mileage out of it just by retrying it and learning the stages.

The game has a 2-player mode, lets you save replays, and has online leaderboards. Apart from the Arcade/Novice difficulties to adjust difficulty, the game has 4 different modes - normal, dynamic difficulty, time attack, and "explosions destroy enemy bullets but enemies shoot a lot more so you need to blow them up at just the right time or you're screwed", each with different quirks but nothing super-major. If you like shmups, you definitely shouldn't let this gem pass you by. If you don't like them, you probably won't like CC. If you don't know whether you like them or not, this is probably a pretty good place to get you started.

33394552.review:
I played vanilla Crimzon Clover a long ways back, managed to 1CC it on UNLIMITED mode after roughly 50 or so hours and I was so satisfied with that accomplishment that I never touched Crimzon Clover again. I knew that an arcade version and WORLD IGNITION came out a while later, but I didn't think too many things changed from the original outside of a new ship and a couple of game modes.

Turns out I was dead wrong and I was a filthy casual. I thought it was hard then, but this right here is something else completely. I didn't know you can make something more challenging than it was before, and even though I'm consistently getting my sphincter torn apart 10 minutes into arcade BOOST mode and 3 stages into UNLIMITED mode, the bigger numbers, the extra breakable parts, more manic patterns, and autistic routing has definitely made it more enjoyable and satisfying compared to the first time I went through it. Crimzon Heart's second form also feels like an actual TLB now instead of some sad attempt at bullet spam. Being given a taste of my own lock-on attack was a damn nice touch, really added to its ridiculous killing intent in its final desperate attempt at survival. Its patterns, combined with both original and arranged music, gives me goosebumps everytime. Out of all the TLBs I've fought, this one really makes it feel like you're both trying to kill each other, especially so during its final attack in which the bullets get faster and more dense the longer you let it live.

If I could refund it and purchase this game along with all its DLC at full price, I definitely would. Restart Syndrome relapsed in the worst imaginable way, and just like Sisyphus, I'm bound to hell. Bullet hell, in this case.

29172217.review:
Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION is the game that may have gotten me into Bullet Hell Shooters. This game does a great job of testing one's reaction time, dodging abilities, and resistance to siezures.

However, there are a few issues that I do have with this game. It can be too difficult and time-consuming at times. With some over-reliance on save scumming that only becomes more of a problem as the levels get longer and more difficult. Even on Novice mode, the game can be incredibly frustrating if you're trying as hard as is possible to avoid getting killed, having to restart levels over and over. But then again, I'm new to this genre; the best advice I can give if you're like me is:
- Stick to the Novice difficulty mode and ignore the Original difficulty.
- Play it purely for catharsis and don't even bother trying to get a high score. It soon becomes extremely difficult to reach the end of a level (let alone the whole game) without losing at least one life, or having to hit Continue (thus resetting your score to zero) at least once.

The other problem I have is that the second ship that you acquire in the game is basically useless due to it's extremely variable bullet spread, making it more of a liability to use than all the others. Also, the fourth ship feels a little overpowered.

Regardless of its difficulty however, the rules do remain fair and consistent. I'm still having a blast with Crimzon Clover, and I'm sure hardcore Bullet Hell and Shoot-'Em Up fans wil get a kick out of it. Good level design, fair and challenging (but occasionally frustrating) gameplay, cool Boss fights, an elegant art style, a funky soundtrack, and a lot of spectacle give this game a very 'arcade' feel.

29155338.review:
Maybe I just don't get it.

I love classic shmups, I really do. I love seeing new takes on the genre, too. But... I couldn't stomach this game too long.

I think I can sum up my main problem with this game as simple visual clutter. The game fills the screen when there's no need to with points, your bullets, backgrounds that blend into enemies. It's a visual mess in a genre that really requires the exact opposite. It's something I expect most people to latch onto, but a few hours (offline. Steam says I only have 36 minutes on this apparently.) into the experience and I just couldn't get over it. The game was an unappealing mess and I felt like just walking away.

Maybe it's just not for me. I do kind of pefer the lighter side of the genre that goes for clarity and depth of mechanics and pattern types instead of the hardcore and visual spectacle side. Maybe I just never got far enough. I just don't get the buzz from here. C'est la vie. Maybe I'll come back to this in a year or two and find I love it.

29137371.review:
STGは下手の横好きの者の目線からのレビューです。
2017年7月からアケでもたまにプレイしています。

このゲーム、弾幕STGなのですが、ノービスモードがあったり
ボスを倒すごとにボーナス要素が一つ貰えるなど、
STGに不慣れな人でも楽しめる設計がなされています。
ノービスモードでは、ボスを撃破すると1UPを貰うことも出来ます。
ボス戦後に1UPを常に貰えば、生存率は確実に高まります。

更に、エクステンドの方法も一定のスコア取得ではなく
☆アイテムを一定数取得することなので、スコアを稼がないプレイでも
エクステンドは定期的に行えます。また、プレイ回数を重ねて
累計の☆アイテムの取得が一定数に達すると、強力な隠し機体が解放されます。
どうしてもクリア出来ない方でも、プレイを重ねていれば
その機体が使えるようになるので、クリア出来る確率もぐっと高まります。
エクステンドのためにスコア稼ぎを意識する必要があるSTGは多いですが
このゲームはその必要がなく、気楽にプレイしやすいと感じます。

私のメインでプレイしている「格ゲー」というジャンルにも言えるのですが、
STGも先鋭化が進み、とっつきにくいジャンルと思われている所があります。
が、このゲームは上記のように親切設計です。かといって
上級者の方をないがしろにしているわけではなく、高難度のモードもあり、
様々な腕前の人が様々な楽しみ方を出来るようになっています。

上級者の方には物足りないかもしれませんが、1周オンリーのゲームなので、
気楽にプレイできるというのもプラスだと思います。やっぱり2周目があると
どうしても2周目を勘定に入れて、2周目行けなかったら残念…とか思う方が
いらっしゃると思うんです。ゲーマーの性として。ってか私がその一人なんですが。
また、2周の場合単純にプレイ時間が長くなるので、気楽にやりづらいというのもあります。
そんな無駄に注文の多い私には、1周というのは丁度良いと感じました。

上記の理由により、間口の広いゲームなので、STG初めての方にもお勧めです。
他のSTGは他機種に移植されているものも多いですが、このゲームは
Steamにしか移植されていないので、「Crimzon Cloverが家でプレイできるのは
Steamだけ！」という得した感も味わえます。最近はネットでの協力や
対戦プレイが全盛の時期ですが、一人でのんびりプレイ出来るゲームも楽しいですし
是非オアシスとしてこのゲームを活用されてはいかがでしょうか？
アケ派の方も、気楽に練習できる環境があるのは良い事ですし。

素晴らしい作品をありがとうございます。

28317082.review:
A gorgeous shmup with great art, music, and gameplay. 

The spherical lock missile system is great, since a lot of other shmups tend to relagate the lock window to where you're aiming and/or in a cone. 

Also glad I can quarter crunch infinite continues to see most everything the game has to offer, though there's apparently some further content for those willing to put in the time and effort to reach the higher eschelons of skill. 

While the gameplay requires the strategic use of bombs to not die regularly, it's still a blast. Badump tsh. 

Very much a modern arcade shmup. It'll eat your quarters until you earn the skill required to 1cc.

Edit: ONE Downside is the high ranking player replays locked behind a DLC paywall. Not necessary for me, but videos of high level play ought to be easy enough to come by that it's odd to see it as DLC.

28266321.review: This game doesn't look special, but it's among the best of the genre.

28110946.review:
This is a fine game, but I wouldn't recommend it to ANYONE but people really into bullet hell shmups.

The presentation, visual and audio, is bombastic, but it ended up feeling repetitive and hollow. The screen is so LITERALLY full of bullets that it can be hard to tell which bullets are yours and which are the enemy's when using the blue shots from Type-II.

The only other bullet hell games I've really played are the Touhou games, and they have more of a rhythm too them. The backgrounds and bullet patterns change with different boss phases. It's like the difference between eating plain yogurt and plain yogurt in a parfait.

The BOOST difficulty mode, which raises as you stave off bomb use and lowers when you activate bombs, is really interesting, but it was hard for me to feel shifts in difficulty within it.

The ship gimicks are also standard and didn't alight my imagination much. The spritework is damn fine, but the designs don't venture outside of typical space shooter at any point. Excellent execution on bland designs.

So, I don't know if this offers anything to the layman.

28098607.review: This game is almost perfection in game design. It's difficult to fathom this was made by one person. The only thing holding it back is not having an option to have no respawn shield (unless I'm an idiot and missed that option). I hate that crutch - if there's a danger of instant death on respawn you could have an option to just remove a TINY number of bullets in the vicinity (like a mini "smart bomb"). I hate waiting so long to get back to the dodging. Otherwise, mind blowing game.

27998924.review:
Crimzon Clover may be one of the most approachable top-down "bullet hell"-style shooters I've ever played. This isn't to say it's not challenging, there certainly are more than enough tight, fast patterns of instant-death bullets, lasers and occasional boss hug of death. For the most part, though, the difficulty seems fair and, at times, even fun. Personally, I found that the game really comes alive when playing the game's "boost mode," where you can trade away your screen-clearing defensive measures for increased offensive power and a large boost in score.  It also helps with the approachability that the game flows really well, to the degree where it feels to me that most of my deaths come from getting so into locking on to multiple enemies for extra points. I don't even care about score that much, it's just that fun to do.

Crimzon Clover is one of those bullet-hell games I reccomend heartily to anyone with even a passing interest in the genre. Come join me, and we can all get together and scream at the top of our lungs about that one vulcan-dwelling mecha-spider.

27885288.review:
Uno dei migliori shump presenti su steam e senza dubbio un must have per gli appasionati del genere.
CC è un gioco adatto a tutti,le meccaniche sono immediate quanto profonde, il sistema del break mode che permette di cancellare i proiettli e aumentare la potenza di fuoco è sicuramente la vera perla di questo gioco ma anche il level design ,il comparto grafico e soprattuto le ost sono di altissimo livello.

Nel gioco sono presenti 2 difficoltà novice e arcarde:
la novice si divide in boost mode e original (la modalità di gioco principale), come dice il nome è adatta a chi gioca agli shmup per la prima volta o magari non ha molta esperienza con il genere non risulta particolarmente difficile.
Il gioco però splende davvero a difficoltà arcade: oltre alle due modalià precedenti si aggiungono il time attack che consiste in un singolo livello dedicato allo score e l'unlimited mode.
A difficoltà arcade il gioco è difficile (tanto) non è paragonabile alla novice mode e già dal terzo livello in poi la densità di proiettili diventa altissima, solo giocando parecchio e utilizzando la training mode si può pensare di fare un 1cc dell'original.
Per quanto riguarda l'unlimited mode... prima di scegliere questa modalità il gioco vi informa che è solo per gli esperti e per una giusta ragione perchè già dai primi secondi del livello 1 verrete inondati da una pioggia di proiettili che vi farà domandare se questa modalità è pensata per esseri umani.

In conclusione, Crimzon Clover è un gioco divertente e sicuramente da provare sia come introduzione agli sparattutto a scorrimento ma anche come una vera sfida per i più appassionati.

26288992.review:
There's still something worth fighting for! Try beating the level 5 boss without using a continue!


Never before has a vertical scroller shoot'em'up been so powerful. 

Become invincible and gain extra firepower when using the Break system, which can be activated to unleash a super powerful shot that covers the majority of the field for a brief period, deflecting most bullets upon activation. Charge it twice and you'll get Double Break mode, an even more powerful version of break.

Adopt various playstyles after shooting down enemy bosses, by looting the different power-ups released by them. Lock-on and unleash various types of damage upon the targeted enemy. The bosses are, in order of appearance:

[b]Titanix[/b] - A ground based mobile fortress defending the Armoured City, 

[b]Hecatoncheir[/b] - A six-armed robot defending the canyon that leads to the secret cavern entrance to the base. 

[b]Maelstrom[/b] - An extermination type base defense cannon protected by flower petal shaped armour, defending the exit of the cave the player entered from stage 2. 

[b]Diabolos[/b] - A flying, modular mobile weapon  with a a fleet of small carriers, protecting the base from the sky.

[b]Gorgoneion[/b] - A massive computer like device constantly absorbing data of unknown content and building new weapons to protect itself. 

[b]Crimson Heart[/b] - The true final boss, unlocked after clearing through Gorgoneion without using continues. Little is known about it, except that it resembles the default sprite of Type Z, adding to the mystery of why it would appear after Gorgoneion appears and the player has apparently stopped a kind of apocalyptic event, as hinted at in the text that which appears before Gorgoneion. 


Collect star points to unlock extra credits and the Type Z shot. Use three shot types. Type I, which is available from the start, and has a slow speed, but higher damage, Type II, which has a "rolling" style of shot and higher speed, and Type Z (has a sprite identical to the Crimson Heart boss), which has a very wide and very high damaging shot. Hold lock-on while selecting it and the sprite will change to a re-coloured Type A, causing further mystery by sharing design with the Crimson Heart. 

Play three separate game modes. The first is original mode, which uses the standard gameplay mechanics, with no modifications to the basic break, bomb, and life system. The second is simple mode, which works with a rank system. Break cannot be activated, but is instead triggered by filling the gauge all the way up. Fill the break gauge to also increase bullet speed in three intervals (0%-49%, 50%-99%, and 100%) and game difficulty as power increases. Shoot enemies at point blank in full break to cause massive star points to appear. Finally, unlimited mode, which is identical to original except performing a shoot down with fully charged lock on will release a shower of star points and greatly increase the difficulty.

These key features truly make Crimzon Clover outstanding. Its name is a reference to a species of clover native to Europe. An indie bullet hell game developed by Yotsubane. It was released for Windows in Japan in 2011, the arcade version was released in 2013 and WORLD IGNITION was released worldwide on Steam in 2014. Get it now, the lucky clover will be in your heart ♥

26097511.review:
[h1]A review for those who are - like myself - new to true Bullet Hell games[/h1]

I've played my fair share of super hard games like most gamers who grew up in the 80s. But with that said, while I'm a veteran of the Gradius, Darius, and R-Type series, and I grew up with all the old staples like Xevious and 1942, I've never played what I would term a "true" bullet hell before. The closest I ever got was some of the old Raiden games in arcades back in the day. 

But by the time daijun games really started to take off in the West, I like many gamers had moved on from 2D and arcade to more immersive 3D fare. It's only been as I've aged that I've 
begun to desperately pine for the old ways. And as such, I've found myself this month on a  massive shmup kick. 

So if you're like I was, you might wonder what exactly this game is all about. What makes this game different than other shmups you may have played? What exactly is a bullet hell game 
anyway? Are they just insanely hard? Do you need the reflexes of a Jedi Knight ninja on speed to stand any chance at all? What's it all about?

[h1]The absolute basics[/h1]

Bullet hell games are essentially vertical or horizontal (vertical here) scrolling shmups with one defining characteristic that earns them the name: absolutely harrowing difficulty. You will have to be at your personal peak of hand eye coordination to play this sort of game as you meticulously maneuver through razor thin spaces amongst projectiles and lasers which at times fill the screen dizzyingly. This is not a game for the faint of heart. It's brutally difficult, and it's meant to be.

These games also often lack weapon upgrades or other customization options, as is the case 
here. Instead it's all about pure twitch gameplay and success against overwhelming odds through sheer skill. It really is a refreshingly "pure" form of gaming that goes back to the roots of the industry.

You have two attacks in the game - your frontal laser, which by default fires forward in a wide spread, and a lock on/homing attack which you can hold until locked on to the maximum possible number of targets, or release sooner for quicker strikes. The longer you hold it, the more powerful the attack will be, and the higher the temporary score multiplier you'll receive for your laser shots for a while. While locked on, you move more slowly, and your frontal lasers condense into a tighter band of energy covering less of the screen. Maneuvering between projectiles while changing speeds and attacks in this way, and knowing which to use when, makes up the entirety of the challenge.

As you defeat enemies, you earn stars (called stardust in-game,) and these contribute to your 
score, and your break rate. Your break rate is the speed at which your break meter fills. Once 
full, you may enter break mode, which intensifies and speeds up your attacks. If you double your break meter, once in break mode you may press the button a second time to enter double break, for even more damage. 

By deftly using this to rack up stardust and points when your multiplier is high, and not allowing your break rate to fall too low (it will drop to half of what it was during break mode roughly once you return to normal,) you can try to rack up your score by continually cutting through the most dense waves of enemies while in break or double break. If your break meter fills beyond a red demarcation line, but is not filled, you can also press the break button to clear the screen of most enemies and projectiles with a "bomb" attack. It's usually a panic button in practice when things get overwhelming, especially against bosses.

You have three ships to choose from at the outset. One is slow but has a broad laser attack. The other is middle of the road in speed, and has a variable laser width. And the third is the fastest, but has the narrowest laser width. I personally find Type-III to be the most effective ship... other than the unlockable Type-Z.

The game is only 5 stages long... but I haven't beaten it yet on Novice after 20 hours. :) It's glorious.

[h1]Yes the game is hard... really hard. But you can still enjoy it.[/h1]

The beautiful thing about bullet hells is that they harken back to an era where gaming was still distilled to its barest fundamentals: pew pew. Shoot the things that move, don't get hit. You get hit, you die. It's a simple premise, but if you're never played a game like this before, it can be profoundly overwhelming prospect even for an extremely experienced gamer. But one of the equally great things about the arcade lineage of these titles is that they're all about scoring. As such, when you run out of lives, if you choose to continue your score is completely reset... but continue you can! This means if you're a complete beginner, you can still experiment with the game and try to get to grips with it by dying an unlimited number of times and still seeing all that it has to offer from a sheer content standpoint.

Of course, in my opinion you'd be robbing yourself of the beauty of this sort of game. As I said, I've never played this sort of game before. The closest I ever got to something like this was the Raiden series in arcades. And it's in arcades that the "kind of gamer" I really am was forged. I was never a score chaser. I was always someone who loved to play the games, but was primarily in it to challenge myself... not other players. Some games (like Hang On) I was actually pretty decent at. But many I would be happy just to beat at all. I was always the kid who stood around and WATCHED the other more competitive players strut their stuff. 

It's taken until this era of Twitch for people to appreciate spectating games again but back in the day it was almost just as fun to watch someone trying to beat the local high score for hours, as it was to play yourself. Crimzon Clover is a fantastic game for that sort of experience. You can play Novice difficulty if you aren't great at bullet hell style games, and still get an INCREDIBLY stiff challenge. You can also play co-op with another player (local - no online... if only!) if you like, or just sit back and watch them play. It really does take me back to those childhood days in the arcade, just doing my best to get a little further...one more stage... one more boss... one more wave... one more high score.

And it should be noted that I absolutely SUCK at this kind of game. But it's still an absolutely invigorating blast to play on Novice. Just hard enough to be brutal, without feeling like there's no hope! Trial and error; Improve. And if you're more skilled, then hop into Arcade Mode. Or if you think you're an absolute master of the genre? Take a crack at Unlimited Mode. There are also time attack modes, and Boost, which massively increases your score.

Personally, I refuse to use the continues (but did use Type-Z ship ) Set your own goals for yourself! It's a great first timer's bullet hell, but fantastic for vets too.

[h1]Old arcade look and feel[/h1]

You know that hyper-grainy, yet imminently smoothly animated, high contrast, high color look arcade games used to have? This game, unlike some bullet hells, EXPLODES to life with that precise aesthetic. Even the narrow in-game window contributes to a sense of playing on a cabinet (and there's TATE, rotation, stretching, etc. if you want to.) Just gorgeous.

[h1]Some issues do exist on the technical front. See this topic for details:[/h1]

http://steamcommunity.com/app/285440/discussions/0/348292787753336077/

[h1]So who's it for?[/h1]

If you love straightforward, PURE gameplay driven shmups, and are in the mood for a BRUTALLY HARD game, but one of the best of its kind, give this game a try.

[h1]Who should pass on it?[/h1]

Anyone looking for a long shooter with many more levels, & upgrades or customization. This game is repetitive challenge, not duration. A true arcade game.

26015777.review:
Crimzon Clover lies amidst a sea of shmup offerings yet sinks not by virtue of a significant amount of replay value owing to its modes of play.

All three modes, coming in two difficulties with four possible ships to use, offer an array of technical and dazzling experiences that are sure to satisfy genre occupants. The game's highly-varied difficulty is a product of precise positioning and mechanical knowledge in equal measure; each mode offers its own twist on the formula.

The presentational complexity of some core mechanics is rendered moot by intuitive design and a stage replay feature of fighting game-level customization. Learning the game is a joy and a thrill, and a nearly universal control scheme helps speed things along, though usage of a joystick is highly recommended for later bosses, which should hardly deter long-time genre admirers.

That aside, it would be remiss to neglect the catchy tunes and splendid bullet patterns on display here. There is not a trace of laziness in the boss and enemy design, and this extends to the retro art-style proudly wearing the arcade banner in a sizzling provocation to more modern visual cues.

The usage of color and contrast is subtle yet pronounced, and there is never a moment where projectiles will be positioned unclearly or blindingly - perhaps mundane, yet crucial, as the varying environments are highlighted well thanks to good placement choices. As far as game design goes, the pace never falters, and neither does the challenge.

While never being awe-inspiring as such, anyone fancying electronic melodies will not be disappointed by the melodies showcased.

All in all, Crimzon Clover: World Ignition is an unfortunately titled yet stylistically endowed shmup, a rare breed in a very niche, even endangered, genre. Even if you are not normally a fan of such products, I would recommend picking it up to test your skills and have a good time doing so.

Rating: B+
A good way to spend some time with no major faults to speak of and good, endearing production.

Este juego es... Si Ikaruga es 007, estás ante Chuck Norris. No tiene la jugabilidad refinada del primero pero lo suple con un sentimiento de satisfacción enorme, acaba con todo nada más toquen pantalla viejo (o chica) o tendrás tantas balas como para comer "metal" un año. 
2 dificultades, 4 modos de juego, 4 naves (una de ellas se desbloquea al jugar), puedes guardar el video de tu partida si quieres observarte morir (50 espacios para hacerlo), scores, buena banda sonora (aunque si le dedicas tiempo al juego puede llegar a cansar la música de los menús). La jugabilidad es muuuuy buena con un disparo grosero, lock con misiles, bombas, break y doble break que es donde están los puntos (aparte de sobrevivir claro); un detalle que me encantó y pocos juegos de este género tienen, es que puedes reiniciar nivel o partida desde cualquier punto en el menú de pausa (solo para practicar y recordar patrones, ya que si lo haces tu score no se guardará).
En resumen, para mí es una compra obligada, para muchos es su primer bullet hell y  será difícil para ellos encontrar otros juegos que le lleguen a la primera experiencia que tuvieron con éste.

25335278.review:
Hyper addictif, une tuerie !!!
 
C'est beau, ça explose de partout, et même si c'est trop dur, il y a un mode novice qui est parfait pour les gens comme moi qui adorent ce genre de jeu sans pour autant pouvoir faire le poid en mode Arcade.
L'action est haletante et soutenue, mais dans l'ensemble on arrive à suivre ce qui se passe.
Le mode DOUBLE BREAK défonce tout !! Orgie de scoring et de destruction !
 
Je n'ai pas encore essayé le mode Boost, mais le mode Time Attack est hyper intense, avec un niveau surchargé d'ennemis qu'on doit détruire le plus vite possible si on veut en faire apparaître davantage, le tout en 3 minutes seulement et avec la musique qui va avec.
 
Les combats de boss sont épiques. J'adore le fait qu'ils aient plusieurs parties destructibles, comme le boss 2 qui a ses tentacules qui vous tirent dessus et dont on peut se débarrasser, ou des yeux du boss du niveau 5 qui tirent des rayons laser partout. Et que dire du boss 2 qui fait son retour dans le dernier niveau, cette fois ci se trouvant derrière soi !!
La destruction d'un boss ou d'un mini boss fait apparaître un groupe d'item dont on a le droit de n'en prendre qu'un seul. Parmis eux, il y en a un qui remplit la jauge de break pour continuer à scorer comme un malade.
 
L'ambiance est au rendez vous, avec le niveau 4 qui se passe à fond la caisse dans les airs et le dernier niveau du classique "base secrète" avec le sas du boss final qui s'ouvre...
Le scrolling va parfois très vite et ça ajoute beaucoup à l'ambiance.
 
Le niveau 3 semble être un hommage aux niveau 4 et 5 de Mushihimesama, avec des groupes d'insectes, des grosses fleurs qui libèrent plein de balles et des espèces de dragons volants avec tous les cartilages qui vous tirent dessus. Le stade final du boss de ce niveau me rappelle un la Stone Like des shmup de Treasure aussi dans ses paterns.
 
Le jeu est très, très dur. Pas d'auto bomb ici. Et on peut gagner très peu de vies supplémentaires en mode arcade. En novice par contre, les boss lâchent des 1UP, alors j'ai mes chances pour faire un 1CC !
 
Un défaut pour moi est que les vaisseaux se déplacent trop vite et qu'il est facile de se prendre un tir en voulant esquiver un autre. Du coup je ne joue qu'avec le Type-I. Il faut bien maintenir la touche des missiles, sans les tirer, dans les passages serrés, pour pouvoir se déplacer plus lentement.
 
Dernier mot : ce jeu est AD-DIC-TIF.

The game is a classic SHMUP type and is challenging enough to keep you interested and forgiving enough that even bad players like me can still enjoy the game.

The music is very nice and I reccomend that you play with this music and sfx, nothing else otherwise it ruins the game I feel. 

The enemies have very interesting design and the patterns that come with their projectiles will keep you thinking through the entire stage, if you feel like the first boss is too bland, wait till you fight the third.

There are some issues with the game that I can see, being the star explosions are super distracting and almost cover enemy projectiles making it hard to dodge, and the lock on mode doesn't seem to have much use since the longer the enemies are alive, the more bullets come at you and it doesn't do a whole lot of damage either. [spoiler] I also get baited into projectiles trying to catch stars	[/spoiler]

Overall this feels like a classic arcade game, i'm not sure if it is but I could see this being a popular booth for less hardcore touhou fans. If you have a joystick or some kind of gamepad I highly reccomend playing this with it, just make sure its plugged in and on before you launch the game and there should be no problems.

25099173.review:
I have a strange relationship with Shmups. They are games that I absolutely adore, where the focus is that primal arcade style of gameplay where the goal is to get good at it and nothing else. And I absolutely suck at them.

So, i'm not an expert on shmups, if that's what you are searching here. However, my review is intended for the people who don't usually play this kind of game and are somehow interested.

Not only is this a shmup, but it's a bullet hell shmup. Those words might send you imediate images of screens filled with colorful bullets that seem completely undodgeable, and you wouldn't be wrong thinking that.
It's a very fast paced and frenetic game where your eyes are completely glued to the screen in awe of the spectacle happening in front of you, making impossible dodges and destroying all kinds of machinery shooting different patterns of bullets at you, complemented by a gorgeous pixel art and a bombastic soundtrack.

The great thing about the game is how it eases you into it, with a Novice mode, which really isnt as easy as the name might make it sound. The bullets are less intense, but you wont make it to the end without wasting a few continues on your first tries.
There is also a great mechanic where you get to use a bullet erasing bomb that is available when you fill a meter, saving your ass alot of times.

Since you dont have to waste quarters to get continues, you have to set your own goals for yourself, otherwise you can just keep on dying and moving forward with unlimited continues.
Luckily the game teases you with secret content if you manage to beat the last boss with just one continue. Even in Novice mode this proved to be a challenging task. But the thrill and rush I got when I reached that last boss on my first continue, beat him and faced the true final boss really was something amazing.
A myriad of bullets flashing and homing on me, as I held on for dear life with one life left. Beating that boss on my first try totally made the game worth it for me.

After that, you have the Arcade mode and the even harder Unlimited mode , which I have no chance of beating on one continue an im totally fine with that, and other modes that slightly change the way you play the game.
People like to be elitists about Dark Souls being a game for "real gamers" and "not for casuals", but this game makes Dark Souls look like a Kirby game. Only a handful of players will master this game.

Buy it for a well spent weekend, and if you enjoy it as much as I do, you might find yourself spending time trying to beat Arcade mode in one continue, even if deep down you know your hands and brain have no chance of dodging every goddamn bullet the game is throwing at you.

10/10 would scream at my screen again

24049871.review:
Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION is a shoot 'em up (as know as Shmup or STG) game released worldwide for PC in 2014. Within the shmup genre, this game belongs to a sub-genre known as Danmaku or Bullet Hell,  characterized by a gameplay fast, intense and frantic with the enemies "urinating" bullets all the time, defying dexterity and motor skills of the player who often have millimetric spaces to dodge the bullets and hit your enemies. Crimzon Clover was developed by a single person, Yotsubane, for five years and he really did a great job, because this game is great! very tasty and fun to play! 23849554.review:
very good . ★★★★★☆

[h1]特徴＞[/h1]
STG(シューティングゲーム)によくあるパワーアップアイテムが無いため、高火力から出陣です。
したがって、アイテムを取る動作が不要となり、集中してプレイが可能となります。
代わりにゲージを消費して、ボムやブレイクを発動することが可能となってます。
ブレイク中にゲージがＭＡＸになれば、スーパブレイク状態になり、
プレイヤーは更に派手なエフェクトに爽快なSTGを楽しむことが可能となります。
ブレイク中には、得点にボーナスが追加されるため、スコアーが、がんがん上っていきます。
もう１つ面白いのは、ロックオンがあること。
これによって、３６０°追尾攻撃(∞）が可能となりました。
つまり、前方以外の攻撃可能となりますので画面全域がフィールドとなるのです。
その分、全方位の弾幕を意識しないといけません。

[h1]内容＞[/h1]
●難易度は２つ。
①ノービス(初心者向け難易度）
＞STG未経験者向けと言えます。気軽に遊べれるし、練習にもいい難易度。
②アーケード（上級者向け）
＞ゲーセンのあの手ごたえが味わえます。（ノービスから一気に難易度が上がります）

●モードは４つ。
①オリジナルモード（基本モード）
＞アーケード版は、激難。（死ねます）
②ブーストモード
＞ブレイクタイムが長いのが特徴。
ボムを使ったり、落ちない限り、永久ブレイク状態（無双）でＴＵＥＥＥできる。
ただ、スーパーブレイクは使用不可。
③アンリミテッドモード（アーケード専用のみ）
＞②オリジナルモードのさらに上、地獄。（実績有）
④タイムアタックモード（アーケード専用のみ）
＞専用ステージで３分間、高スコアーを狙うモード。

●使用機種は３機＋１機（隠し機）
※１ＰＣ共有プレイ良好。

[h1]感想＞[/h1]
やられる前に倒せ！派手で爽快なゲーム！パチ○コ屋！一見そう思いますが、
それだけではなく、弾幕もしっかりしているし、
それぞれのステージの敵の配置もすばらしい。
ＳＴＧの中では格別です。
クリムゾンクローバーは、昔にゲーセンでちょろっと遊んだ程度。
ほとんどSTGやらないのですが、これは楽しい。
STGがこんなに面白いとは。ＢＧＭも、実績集めも良い。
価格も手ごろですし、遊んでほしい。
∞コンテニュー設定なので、STG初心者にも入りやすいと思います。
開発者はノーコンテニューを推薦してるようですが、
実際にsteamの積みゲーマーは何人クリアーできるのだろうか。

予断ですが、フレンドのほとんどが開発済みで、
steamで開発可能ってことは最近まで知らなかったです・・・。


評価額＝１５００円

23447194.review:
[b]One of the best.[/b]

As a fan of shooting games, coming fresh off of many Cave staples, I've come to enjoy Crimzon Clover more than any other. Not only is it my favorite, it has become the new baseline for which I like to judge all others. 

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Like most vertical STGs, Crimzon Clover follows many of the same rules set down by the genre. You have 3 ships (later 4) with varying balances of speed and weapon spreads, the standard shot/laser with slower movement, a small hitbox, and bullet clearing bombs. Two things which set CC apart are its enemy locks and break mode. 

By holding down the lock button, your ship will attempt to lock on to as many nearby targets as possible. Releasing said button will launch out missiles towards those targets. This design really harkens back to Star Fox; if you're familiar with it, same principle. Unlike Star Fox, though, your score multiplier is based on the continual success of these lock ons. The more enemies you lock onto and hit, in one salvo, gives you a proportionate score multiplier for a few seconds. So, for high score, you’re looking to lock on to a group of enemies, get a high multiplier, use it to gain a lot of points on the next batch, and repeat.  

Break mode is the main gimmick of Crimzon. After successfully filling a meter, you have the ability to transform into break mode. The transformation itself lends a second of invulnerability, good for saving bombs and lives. Once transformed, you’re granted several benefits. Firstly, and most noticeably, your firepower increases significantly. It’s likely you’ll be clearing the entire screen throughout the duration. Second, you’re given a higher lock multiplier limit. This means everything you’re blowing up with all those flashy lasers is possibly dumping thousands and millions of points down. If you manage to fill both meters, 200%, you can break again for another moment of invulnerability, and double these benefits. Because this mode is so valuable, most score routes are very defined by when you break.

All other mechanics are simply best in class. The movement feels like any arcade STG. The bosses are challenging yet patternful. The stages do have a nice incline of difficulty and there are certainly a slew of true last bosses to unlock by 1CCing.  

[b]Graphics/Sound:[/b]
I feel like if the first 5 seconds of stage 1 don’t sell you, nothing will. The bombastic opening fanfare, the emerging of the carrier, launching of your fancy hitbox, and a moment of calm where you’re likely already spamming a screen full of bullets all compose it. That whole slice of cake is a perfect feel for the rest of the game. It’s fast, it’s bright, it’s arcadey, and the music is constantly up-tempo and pumping. This isn’t to say the game’s soundtrack is a cranked burner with nothing in the pot. Stages 4 and 5 especially have these moments where the soundtrack just wanders through amazing moments which fit the onscreen action. I’ve actually come to time many of my routes and timings on the musical cues. The music is there to support the manic action happening on the screen. 

[b]Replayability:[/b]
I know STG games and bullethell shmups are a tough genre to sell people on. Crimzon Clover offers a nice set of different modes, unlocks, achievements, and most importantly a novice mode. I cannot stress how well done the novice mode is. Do not over pride yourself by going straight into the normal modes without being a veteran of the genre. This game will live up to its root and kill you outright on normal and beyond. That isn’t to say you can’t fully enjoy it on novice. This is equally true for players familiar with the genre. Novice mode will still kill you, and not an easy 1CC. 

If you just want to spam continues and bombs and get to the credits, then this won’t be a fun game. These games were not meant to be quarter fed for a win, anybody can do that. The point is to repeat them again and again until you’re able to beat it without using a single continue and/or achieving a higher score than your friends (or the world). All of Crimzon’s replayability is crutched by this design aspect. It is very much an enjoyable game to repeat again and again. It’s fun trying out different ships, different tactics, different routes and scoring strategies, learning boss patterns, etc. I encourage anybody new to the genre, playing this, to go ahead and play through the game a couple times over. Count how many times you continued each run and see how it shrinks, see your high score get higher. Trust me, it’s as addictive as modern rogue-likes, and a reason why the genre is still popular amongst gamers. 

= = = = = = =

Don’t shy away from the stigma of the genre. It’s a really fun game and well worth the price. You’d be hard-pressed finding a better shooting game, especially on Steam.

One of the best shmups on Steam. Crimzon Clover offers a fairly CAVE-like experience, but stands alone enough for those that want something a little bit different from a real CAVE game. The break mechanic is interesting and will give you plenty of game time figuring out just the right time to use it. There are plenty of different modes on offer, including Boost mode (Variable Difficulty), the original Arcade mode, the obligatory super hard Unlimited mode, and a seperate Time Attack mode for you scorechasers out there. If you've never played a bullet hell game and want to see if the genre is for you, Crimzon Clover is a great starting point.

The DLC is largely skippable, but I found the Superplay DLC to be quite useful in helping improving my scores. It is a very niche product, however. The real value comes from the included commentary from the players, rather than the replays themselves.

22255197.review:
Je suis nul en Shmup et je n'avais jamais touché à un Danmaku, bullet hell ou autre dénomination pour le genre si particulier de l'esquive boulette.

Pour les débutants, il faut opter pour le novice et vraiment le faire dans tous les modes possibles avec un bon niveau pour espérer se frotter au mode Arcade. Dans ma grande prétention, je me suis dit que le novice étant assez accessible (2ème boss sans mourir au premier essai ), l'Arcade devait être à ma portée et j'ai déchanté. Le palier est tellement haut que je me suis fait eclater à peine le premier niveau commencé. 
Passer cette petite claque, le jeu pète de partout et reste lisible (Sisi, je vous assure que l'on arrive sans problème à distinguer les boulettes à éviter). C'est dynamique, ultra nerveux et jouissif.

3 vaisseaux différents ( Vitesse et puissance), 3 boutons en plus des directions : le tir, les missiles (le tir principal se resserre pendant le lock des ennemis) et le break mode ( Le tir est plus puissant et ça peut faire office de bombe avant de lancer). Simple, efficace et intuitif.

Dans les reproches à faire parce qu'il faut en faire : L'écran est petit ( Le genre veut ça) et il manque la dénomination des touches pour savoir lesquelles utiliser au début ( Manette Xbox 360 : A pour tirer, X pour le break mode et B pour les missiles).

En résumé, c'est le genre de jeu qui peut vous accrocher des heures ou vous laisser de marbre. Les shmups arrivent en force sur Steam avec Cave, notamment. Il semble un bon moyen de découvrir le genre à un prix raisonnable (Il est régulièrement en promo).

22049732.review:
This game is godly. Go play it, no matter how good you are at bullet hell.

PROS:
- It's very approachable. If you were a complete newbie to the bullet hell genre, you would still be able to blaze through the game on Novice Mode, with unlimited continues, while if you were a shmup killing machine, you would still have lots of fun playing for score on Arcade Mode.
- The soundtrack is amazing. It manages to capture the stages' atmospheres perfectly. Plus, it's ripped straight from the arcade, for the nostalgic feel for some.
- It's very well-designed. Everything from enemy placement, to enemy amount, was carefully and cleverly adjusted, so that you can feel like you're actually creating completely new strategies, while in reality, the developers expected your every move.
- Clever, well hidden safespots.
- An actual FAIR AND DODGEABLE TLB. I KNOW RIGHT?!

CONS:
- Some stages can be a stray bullet hell. You honestly have no idea how many times I died, just because I didn't notice that one small bullet that wasn't deleted in time.
- Sometimes, my homing shots just wouldn't lock on, for some reason.
- Stage 3 is way harder than Stage 4. (Goddamn enemies with hitboxes.)

No, seriously, go play this game.

21866535.review:
いわゆる縦スクロール弾幕シューティングゲームです。ただ、モードによっては弾量より弾速が目立つ印象で、速弾系の要素も少々備えた弾幕系STGといったところ。作り込まれたグラフィックと派手な演出が非常に爽快な気分にしてくれます。

　自機に搭載されているのはフルオートのショット、低速も兼ねたロックオンショット、ボンバーと二段階のハイパーで、プレイ中は3つのボタンを使用します。この手のジャンルに慣れている方なら操作を覚える点で苦労することはまずないでしょう。
　NOVICEとARCADEという二つの設定それぞれにORIGINALとBREAKという二種類のモードがあり、ARCADEには加えて、高難易度化するUNLIMITEDとやや変わり種のTIMEATTACKというモードもあります。難度はNOVICE系、ARCADE系、UNLIMITEDの三段階と大まかにまとめられるかも。
　NOVICEは初見で思うがまま立ち回ってもさほど嫌らしい弾は飛んできません。何度かプレイして要所を見極め心の準備をしていけば、この手のジャンルは初体験というプレイヤーも楽しめるレベルだと思います。ARCADEはゲーセン通いのシューター向けの歯応えある調整。UNLIMITEDはアケシューで2周したりスコアを切磋琢磨する上級プレイヤーも納得の難易度だと思います、私は2面で力尽きました。

　アイテム、ゲージ管理、スコアの仕様は少々複雑です。プレイ自体はとっつきやすいものの、ARCADE以降の凶悪な後半面を生き延び、スコアを残すには、システムを把握し味方につけられるかどうかの勝負という側面も色濃いです。
　また機体間の難易度格差が結構あります。type IIとtype IIIは性能面で差別化されつつも同格と言えるでしょうが、初期カーソル位置のtype Iはこれに大きく劣り、隠し機体のtype Zはtype Iの完全上位互換で他機に劣る要素が皆無なほどの超万能機です。この格差はNOVICE-ARCADE-UNLIMITEDの大きな難度差を埋めるためのデザインかも。

　グラフィックは非常に美麗です。ボスは多彩な形態変化を見せますし、すべてのボスが部位破壊演出を備えていることは特筆に値します。雑魚敵についても細かい砲塔の動き、中破演出、撃破時の破片、ステージへの破壊痕など全く手抜かりがありません。steamでプレイできるSTGの中でも最高峰に位置するグラだと思います。多脚多関節でうにうに動く2ボス、砲塔をわんこそばの如くおかわりする4ボスなどは個人的に必見。キャラクターに関しては、可愛い女の子どころか渋いおっさんすら一切出てきません。自機とステージと敵メカが全ての直球勝負！
　音楽はあくまで個人的判断ですが、無難な出来ながらもややパンチに欠ける印象でした。個性的で良質な音楽を第一に求めてSTGをするというプレイヤーは不満足に終わるかも。ただステージによっては二種類BGMが用意されているのは嬉しいです。

　メカメカしい雰囲気のゲームが好みのプレイヤー、破壊の爽快感を味わいたいプレイヤー、システムを研究し倍々に伸びていくスコアを眺め達成感を得たいやり込みプレイヤーにオススメです。良いゲームです。

21448525.review:
Sto cominciando ad avere un certo rigetto per i bullet hell. Ho notato quanti shooters, specialmente indipendenti, si rifanno a queste meccaniche. Stanno veramente cominciando a saturare il mercato per questi shooters (rendendo obsoleti shooter come Gradius) ma, fortunatamente, Crimzon Clover World Ignition si pone al di sopra di molti altri bullet hell.

Questo gioco non è un casino dove le strategie devono essere precisissime o dove lo scermo è così zeppo di proiettili da non vedere più nemmeno la tua navicella; Crimzon Clover è il perfetto bilancio fra strategia e divertimento senza scadere necessariamente nella follia. Certo, esistono modalità più brutali, ma Crimzon Clover può essere acquistato anche da quelle persone che vogliono cimentarsi in questo genere vista la modalità boost che si regola a seconda dell'abilità del giocatore e la bellissima grafica 3D pre-renderizzata (l'ho sempre trovata favolosa) che permette di distinguere ogni elemento nello schermo. Questo shooter si rifà ovviamente agli shooter Toaplan/Cave senza essere scadere nel plagio grazie all'interessantissmo sistema break/double break, che da al gioco un tocco di tanta originalità quanta follia, e al radar che permette di eliminare i nemici lontani dal fuoco della navicella. Veramente belle le navicelle, molto bilanciate, gli stage sempre ben disegnati e "affollati quanto basta". 

Anche i non esperti possono cimentarsi in questo gioco, Crimzon Clover  World Ignition è un gioco ottimo. Per i bullet hell questo è un gioco validissimo poichè non scade nelle solite cose del tipo mettere una ragazzina che spara laser dalle dita o rendere la difficoltà ad un labirito di proiettili. è veramente bello come questo gioco sia retro ma non troppo poichè, anzichè andare a produrre una, ormai stra-usata, grafica 8 bit, si ferma in un punto fra il 96 e il 97 e riporta quella bellissima grafica di quel periodo. In questo Crimzon Clover vince a mani basse. è un gioco veramente old school e se siete amanti e/o esperti degli shooter Toaplan/Cave compratelo subito.
Non consigliatissimo per una prima esperienza, fatevi le ossa con Gradius o Blazing Star... e poi tornate! :)

9/10

21089575.review:
結論から述べますと、この弾幕STGは同人弾幕STGでも最高峰の出来です。曲も演出も良いし、ストーリーも何も用意されてないくせに意味深な5面のメッセージ演出も全てが好みでした。弾幕STGに抵抗感が無い人や、東方をやったことのある人は今すぐ買いましょう。何年インベントリに眠らせておいても良いです。ある日ちょろっとNOVICEモードだけでも遊んでください。NOVICEの5面をクリアしてください。
ボムやBREAK MODEの発動に必要なブレイクゲージは、敵の近くでショットを撃つと物凄い勢いで溜まるようです。ダブルブレイク状態で敵を撃つと、物凄い勢いで星アイテムが貯まります。
そうして星を稼げば、残機が増えます。残機が増えればもう少し長く遊べます。

この弾幕STGは相当難しいです。
エフェクトはとても派手で初めの頃はしょっちゅう自機を見失うし、TYPE-Iの攻撃は弱いし、TYPE-IIIは移動が速過ぎます。かといってTYPE-IIは独特の子機の操作に慣れません。正直最初は攻略する気にはなれませんでした。よくあるパターンです。
それでも文句言いながら、1面にしては長いステージの攻略を続けてる内に、スティックをどれくらい倒すと自機はどれくらい動くというのが分かってきます。それに伴って自機を見失うことも少なくなるし、ボムを撃つタイミングもなんとなく分かってくる。
ていうか、NOVICEモードがあるじゃんと思って、それをやっていたんですけれども。
ある日気付いたら、なんかTYPE-Zとかいう松ぼっくりみたいな機体が解禁されているんですよ。どうやら星アイテムの累計で解禁されるそうな。
こいつがめっちゃ強い。常にTYPE-IのBREAK MODEが発動しているのでは？と思えるほどの攻撃範囲の広さと、攻撃力の高さを備えています。
TYPE-Zを解禁したらもう勝ちです。このゲームは余裕です。うそです。結局3面で残機が無くなります。
ここで折れそうになりました。でも悔しかったのです。インターネットランキングのリプレイを見ていると、上手い人は想像もつかない動きでDOUBLE BREAKを発動し、自分が死んだ時に持っていた星アイテムの数を2面の道中で超えていく。そこで、自分はまだこのゲームの楽しさを理解していないのでは？と感じたのです。でなきゃあそこまでやり込めるはずが無いだろうと思ったのです。
そう感じてからは毎日上手い人のリプレイを見返して、ひたすら動きの真似をしていました。実績を見ると、TYPE-Zを解禁してから20日ほどでノーコンティニュークリアを達成したようです。本当に嬉しかった。
つまりはゲームの攻略に迷ったら人に聞けということです。

20817057.review:
A decent Arcade style Shoot em up, its got good music, good sound, good 2D graphics. You get 4 kinds of ships, one is unlockable, all ships only differ in shot width and movement speed. Basically this is some nice old fashioned arcade action. You fill your gauge up and get breaker and double breaker modes, doubling then trippling your fire power.

When you activate that breaker mode, you unload on your enemies, they start exploding, the screen starts shaking, god damn it's a good feeling. You also have this other weapon, basically a missle system. You hold the button down, enemies around you get marked, then when you release the button, missiles get fired at them; while you hold this button down, you move a bit slower.

Why do I not recomend this game though? Because of 2 flaws:

1.) Your ship moves way too freaken fast, every ship has two speeds, fast as shit, and too fast. As you need to dodge a lot of bullets in this game, many of which slow moving, that means you need to move through some pretty tight spaces. Try doing that at top speed, you can't be precise enough to survive. The slowest speed your ship goes, is just too fast.

2.) The slow down button is also an attack button. So when you hold down the missle button, you move slow, but when you release it to fire the missiles, you suddenly go super sonic speed. And since your holding then releasing the button often, you basically shift from moving ultra fast, to just fast. Try dodge bullets while doing this! In the later levels, there are some things that you need to kill as fast as possible, while dodging bullets. So that means holding and releasing the missle button, which makes to shift speeds. It is agonizing.

Aside from that the game is just very generic, theres nothing really new in terms of weapons or level design. Despite that, it could still be fun if not for the above problems.

I must say I do enjoy the game up to the end of level 2, but level 3 and beyond it becomes purely anoying.

20721681.review: uno de los mejores Shmups que he jugado :3

20691981.review:
There is a popular AAA game whose trailer says: [h1]“Do you know the definition of insanity?”[/h1]

Well, the answer is Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION.

[h1]Story[/h1]

There is no story, you just fire!

[h1]Gameplay and mechanics[/h1]

Well, it is quite simple, fire, keep shooting, collect stars and score as high as you can, try not to die and keep firing!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The graphics on these kind of games is the one we grew up playing with, so there is no problem if they look outdated or not enhanced or whatever, we don’t care, that’s why I like these games, it’s all about the fun and the insanity. Crimzon Clover is a good example of old shooters that we don’t see much around, but that clearly keeps that feeling of an arcade machine, the claustrophobic sensation of the screen, the gazillion bullets and effects that barely let you see where you are standing, dodging and avoiding damage! Superb!!!

[h1]Sound[/h1] 

Clearly on par with graphics, it does a good job, though, the music is clearly overshadowed by the sound effects. Overall, it doesn’t matter, just keep firing!

[h1]The bad[/h1]

Nothing! Maybe the length, a minor detail.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION is a game that definitely brings back good old memories, it has all the elements of the classic bullet hells/shooters of old time, it is extremely fun, though, short in length, but with some extra modes that will add more fun and challenges to the already challenging gameplay on arcade mode. I totally recommend this game to old school veterans and overall to newbies that did not have the chance to enjoy the arcade machine time.

This game is INSANE!

20599131.review:
First, a contented sigh

....

Now let me tell you about my little experience with the saintly clover. For the keen eye Cave's two color shot and speeds with score system and hyper mode (aka Break Mode) , some layer locking and secondary shot slowdown, AND even Cho Ren Sha's "trinity" Power-up all says you're in for a good time. Seriously the amount of cues to the now staple systems for vertical games is very refreshing and respectful, one could keep this title as a reference for those who are just getting into or interested in the genre.

Another note is that the whole package feels right, especially for the balanced use of freeware and in-house assets. The shot, ship, and swarm speeds are all there and on point. The different mode further tailor the experience to your battle mood. Simply solid delivery across the arcade board.

About the only thing I'm holdong out for, if not hoping for is the incoming titles to have a "sweet definiton" - that one token mechanic that you notice that says iconic. Double Break mode is a close second, still leaves me wanting more.
C. Clover as a whole has near iconic quality, yet for it to make its own would really shine. I want the feels, the excitement is only one part.

Mind you though, the above is just an over time sentement. This is a key modern arcade shooter for the budding pilot and 'core grazer' alike.

19634978.review:
CC:WI is an extremely addictive, fun and difficult ‎'Dōjin Bullet Hell' Game developed by Japanese Developer 'Yotsubane' released on the 6th of June, 2014.

I've got to say, The amount of fun you can have just by paying $9.99 AUD is astounding, The game is brilliantly put together; Every little detail to the game looks like it was worked on countless times to make it as good as it can be, The controls are amazing aswell, Being able to use a Controller or just your Keyboard to play the game. Whoever composed the music in the game deserves a hundred medals! It fits the mood of the game near perfectly and always helps to listen to when you are feeling down.
The only thing i'm dissapointed in with this game is the lack of levels, Having only 5 Levels does restrict replayability value somewhat.

The difficulty suits both Beginners and Seasoned Veterans of Bullet Games, The Novice mode is great for beginners and returning players looking to sharpen up and unlimited mode is perfect for Veterans with an extremely high difficulty factor.

My closing thoughts on the game are these:
CC:WI Is a brilliantly though of game with easy and challenging elements with a rocking soundtrack to boot.
While some game Settings are limited everything you need is there with the option to flip your screen sideways, Change keybinds, Switch between using a Controller or Keyboard and the usual Sound Options.
I would most definetely recommend this game to anyone looking to get into the Bullet Hell Genre and also recommend it to Bullet Hell Experts because this game will test even the greatest.

--Ratings--
Game Design - 9.7/10
Game Soundtrack - 10/10
Game Options/Settings - 6/10
Replayability Value - 4/10
Difficulty - 4/10 -:- 10/10
OVERALL - 9.2/10

19107153.review:
Definitly one of my favourite shoot em ups out there !

And although it looks rather intimidating, its rather beginner friendly, if you can get past one of its biggest beginners traps:
Visual Noise.

The screen is cluttered with different visual effects. Your shots, explosions, the point star clusters, targeting rectangles, its a colorfull and vibrant mess to look at.
But in essence, all you need to concentrate on are enemy bullets, which have a very nice contrast and pretty much always stick out like a sore thump. 
It takes some getting used to and it can get overwhelming fast, but if you can manage it, youre in for a treat !

Further enhancing its beginner friendlyness is the lack of power ups. Your ship always starts with its maximum streangth, spay, speed etc, so there is no downside to loosing a life here and there or to worry about reaching a certain power up floating around the stage.
This makes it far easier to concentrate on its core mechanics and omits the need to trow a run because you cant clear a certain section without max stats. (Something i personally call "Gradius Syndrome")

All in all, i wholeheartedly reccomend it for beginners and veterans alike. Its an adrenalin rush from beginning to end, without ever becoming too frustrating or too overwhelming.

If you get this game in a bundle with other things you know you'll like, you wont be dissapointed simply because free games are free. But dont pay for it. 

First off, the screen size, while it can be resized in a rather wonky way, is unplayable unless you already know the key layout or are in a mood to experiment. The buttons youre looking for are Z (a.k.a. start. wtf) x, c, v and the arrow keys. 

The game screen itself even in full screen mode is about the size of a sheet of paper, since the borders on the left and right (which youll probably never even look at. i didnt) take up a third of the screen. EACH.

I'm guessing that my experience with top down shooters is limited compared to the people who overwhelmingly loved this game. I have played classics like life force, gunsmoke, the rtype series, UN squadron, stuff like that on classic consoles. This game is by FAR nothing like those. In this one, instead of playing a game where you pilot a ship to avoid and shoot down enemies, you play some kind of super powered ship of absolute destruction while you try and rhythmically charge lock-on screen wiping bombs and dodge the bullets that some of the (im guessing enemies since EVERYTHING is constantly obscured by massive explosions) manage to squeeze out. there is no point in trying to manuever for a shot, your shit hits practically everything at all times. The only time you need to move at all is if a bullet is going to hit you. In some rare cases, larger enemies and bosses that take more hits will constantly barrage you with undodgeable on hit kill bullets while you try to maneuver (lel) and hit your. . . other. . . bombs and breaks for the breif peroid of invulnerability that will allow you to not lose a life. Not that it matters. 

This game boils down to ' hold z, rhymically hoold and release x, be ready to press c if bullets are going to hit you and press v to continue. 

If you like shooting at explosions, and wiggling around a little, then this game is great.

this game looks like someone watcheed someone playing diablo 3 for 20 seconds, and tried to turn that information into a game.

18416517.review:
I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. 

One Hour Reviews #35 - Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION

I haven't really played very many modern shoot em up games.  My history is more with the old school arcade shooters like Galaga and Galaxian.  Playing this is like seeing these old games on steroids.

Luckily for me, the game provides a choice of difficulty when starting a new game.  So novice players like myself can start with the Novice difficulty instead of Arcade difficulty.  You also get a choice of different modes to play in.  For the Novice difficulty I had the choice of Original or Boost mode.  They looked largely the same except Boost mode modifies the difficulty based on skill.  There is also an Unlimited and Time Attack mode, but these aren't available in the Novice difficulty.  I started with the Original mode.

You get an optional tutorial at the beginning to get a feel of the controls.  I liked that even as a modern shooter, the controls are still pretty simple to pick up.  You have the obvious controls of moving your ship around and firing your main gun.  You also get a secondary weapon where holding down the button will lock onto enemies.  Then when you let off the button you'll fire at everything that has been locked on to.  

The third button I found pretty interesting as it does a couple of different things.  The game has a break mode gauge that fills as you kill enemies.  If you press the button, you'll drop a bomb which is basically an attack that hits the entire screen, but it also has the bonus of making you invulnerable for a short time.  But if the break mode gauge is full, then instead of dropping a bomb you go into "break mode"  In this mode your firepower increases big time for a short duration.  It's also possible to stack up 2 break mode gauges and get a double break mode, which will increase your firepower even more.

All of these weapons can be fired independently.  So for instance while you are firing your main gun at whatever is in front of you, you could be locking on to enemies to your side.  I found myself hitting the bomb at key times when it looked like I'd be unable to dodge the enemy bullets, so I'd get that bit of invulnerability.

The game starts out at a somewhat leisurely pace, but it doesn't take long for things to pick up, and the later levels really get crazy.  But I really appreciated the fact that the developers kept the game very accessible.  In the novice mode I played, I got all the continues I wanted after losing all of my lives.  In the latter stages that happened a lot.  But it seems the developers want you to be able to complete the game, and then focus on getting better at it.  So for the very casual player, you can still have fun blasting your way through the levels and dying a lot without any real penalty.

The 2D graphics are very nice.  There were some parts of the game it got so crazy it started looking like one of those visualizers you see in a music player or a screensaver.  I also really liked the soundtrack and thought it was perfect as the backdrop for an arcade shoot em up.

If you are already a shoot em up fan, then you probably already have this game or don't really need any convincing to pick it up.  But for the more casual players, I can still recommend this game, but you might want to catch it on sale.

18401909.review:
Die perfekte Kugelhölle

Um es gleich vorweg zu sagen: Für mich ist Crimzon Clover Das Beste Shoot'em Up überhaupt und der Grund, warum ich mir überhaupt erst einen Steam-Account zugelegt habe. Gameplay, Design, Musik - Crimzon Clover perfektioniert alles, was in diesem ja doch schon recht alten Genre zählt! Es erinnert stark an das ebenfalls ausgezeichnete DoDonpachi, und ist somit definitiv nichts für Anfänger. Die Mengen an Kugeln welche die sehr schön designten Gegner abfeuern suchen ihresgleichen. Dennoch bleibt meistens ein kleines Loch, durch das man hindurch tauchen kann. Das dadurch entstehende Chaos, in dem es schwer ist, sein eigenes Raumschiff im Auge zu behalten, wird dabei derart episch präsentiert, wie es sonnst nur selten in diesem Genre der Fall ist. Um dich rum explodiert es, die Projektile fliegen in 3d (auch wenn das Spiel an sich natürlich ein waschechter 2d-Shooter ist) und der Untergrund ist detailliert ausgearbeitet. Im laufenden Spiel ist ohnehin soviel los, dass man nicht viel auf den Untergrund achten kann. Trotz allem Kugelhagel wird das Spiel aber nie unfair, so dass mann stets denkt, "Das nächste Mal mach Ich's besser!", und nicht "Was ist das wieder für'n scheiss!".  Insgesamt kann man sagen, dess es sich wie ein typischer Cave Shooter spielt. Würde man mir sagen es wäre ein unbekanntes Shooter-Juwel jener hochverdienten Ballerspiel-Schmiede - Ich hätte es sofort geglaubt. Bevor Cave anfing, seine Meisterwerke über Steam auch PC-Spielern zugänglich zu machen, war Crimzon Clover somit ein ausgezeichneter Ersatz für die fehlenden Cave-Shmups. Man kann das ganze auch zu zweit an einem Bildschrim zocken, was den Spassfaktor nochmal anhebt. Kaum zu glauben, dass Yotsubane dieses Spiel als Ein-Mann-Team entwickelt hat. 
Insgesamt hat man drei Angriffe zur Wahl: Den Standard-Schuss, Raketen mit einer Lock-On-Funktion und einen Hyper-Angriff. Letzteren läd  den man mit dem Aufsammeln von goldenen Sternen auf, welche abgeschossene Gegner verlieren. Ist er voll aufgeladen, kann man Break-Schuss abfeuern, der für ein Paar sekunden das ganze Spielfeld mit Feuer überzieht. Er lässt sich jedoch auch ohne vollständiges Aufladen stufenweise abfeuern, um um in einem Sekundenbruchteil das Spielfeld leerzufegen, und einem so wertvolle Sekunden zu verschaffen, um sich vor dem gegnerischen Speerfeuer in Sicherheit zu bringen.
Wer auch nur etwas Interesse an Bullet-Hell Shmoot'em ups hat, MUSS Crimzon clover Spielen!
Die einzigen Shmups auf Steam, welche an diese Qualität heranreichen, sind Ikaruga und die Shoot'm Ups von Cave, bisher hier auf Steam aber nur durch Mushihimesama, Deathsmiles und DoDonpachi Ressurection vertreten. Ich hoffe, dass bald noch mehr hochkarätige Shmups von Cave und anderen Entwicklern auf Steam veröffentlicht werden. Wenn ihr das auch wollt: 
Kauft dieses Baller-Juwel!

18318957.review:
Great arcade style shoot'em up with colorful graphics, catchy music, and gameplay which is easy to learn but very hard to master.

One thing that sets this game apart from other shoot 'em ups like Raiden IV is that the difficulty is very modifiable making it a lot more accessable to newbies. While this is easily one of the hardest shoot 'em ups ever made when played on the hardest difficulity - on the easier settings it is toned down enough that it's still fun to play and actually possible for less experienced players to beat it on one credit.

As far as gripes go, they are mainly just nitpicks. With only 5 levels (aside from a special time attack level) it is fairly short, and there isn't much content to unlock aside from 1 new ship and a secret boss (which ironically you can play right from the start of the game simply by selecting it in practice mode).

There are also a few music bugs which will hopefully be fixed with a new patch; after completing a game the music clips when returning to the title screen, and when reaching the secret boss the music does not play unless you pause the game and then unpause it. However these are just nitpicks and don't seriously detract from the enjoyability.

18028073.review:
It’s no secret that the presence of shmups has witnessed a decline over the past several years. While some might argue that such an occurrence is par for the course; given that the genre has always found its roots in arcades which have also become exceedingly rare; there are many who would nevertheless consider it a great shame to see a whole genre on the verge of disappearing altogether. Attempts have been made to breathe fresh life into the scrolling shooter, but the number that has been met with favourable commercial and critical results has always fallen shorter than what most shmup fans would have liked to have witnessed. It should be of great interest then to those invested in the fate of the genre to know that Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION is a shmup that comes of only the highest quality.

Crimzon Clover began as a Flash game developed by YOTSUBANE in 2011. After being re-released two years later in Japanese arcades the game was finally remade into what you have here: Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION – an international version of the surprise-hit arcade title. There doesn’t appear to be any overarching narrative to accompany the action of Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION and if there is, then it’s safe to say that it’s nowhere to be found in the game. Then again, games of this nature aren’t known for their need of any grand story in order to deliver the experience expected by their target audience.

The core gameplay of Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION revolves around the concept of the Break Gauge. After choosing from one of four different ships the player is presented with five stages of increasing difficulty, each of which is played in sequence. Defeating enemies using either the standard, forward-firing attack or the powerful homing attack releases scoring items and gradually fills the aforementioned gauge. When the gauge exceeds one of two thresholds the player is granted the ability to use a ‘bomb’ which could be useful should the bullet count start to pile up beyond what one might find manageable otherwise. Refraining from using a bomb enables the gauge to fill even further and upon exceeding a second threshold it becomes possible to enter Break Mode. Doing so dramatically increases the player’s firepower and includes the added benefit of raking in more points, though it should be noted that Break Mode only lasts a limited period of time, after which the player’s attack power and scoring capabilities both return to the default level. 

It’s a great idea that employs the use of several short-term goals to encourage a very aggressive playstyle, one that sees the player always seeking to make the most of their time spent in Break Mode, and immediately looking to re-enter the mode as swiftly as possible following its closure. Enemy placement has been well thought out: weak but fast enemies appear in great numbers often to shield stronger opponents hiding further up the screen. This provides the player with a good opportunity to build up their score multiplier before going after the targets that are worth the most points. The fact that this formula pertaining to the arrangement of enemy formations persists throughout the entire game; and that it consistently yields itself to create a satisfying set of dynamics; is what makes Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION so impressive. It would be hard to find any obvious flaws in the game’s level designs, and for that YOTSUBANE and Adventure Planning Service are to be applauded.

The game includes four different modes of play, most of which can be played solo or with a second player through local co-op. The Original mode of play enables the player to extend their offensive capabilities even further upon breaching a third threshold in order to enter Double Break Mode, while the Boost mode of play automatically forces the player to enter Break Mode upon reaching the second threshold. As long as Break Mode remains active, one’s score increases, although this also comes at the expense of the enemies putting up more of a fight too. The Unlimited mode of play is a true test of how well one knows the game and it wouldn’t be inaccurate to describe it as being one of the most satisfying and rewarding aspects of the game. It puts players in the hot zone from the very beginning and doesn’t let up until all is said and done. Players who have the stomach for it will likely come back to this mode of play time and time again. Last but not least is the Time Attack mode of play, a short, single-player venture in which the player aims to earn as many points as possible within a limited period of time on a stage unique to that mode. Lives are unlimited but that doesn’t make Time Attack any less demanding; nor any less enjoyable; than the rest of the game.

Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION excels in the aesthetics department too. Each of the sprites has been made with meticulous detail, the bullets and various environments all sport a wide variety of different colours and overall the visual feedback provided to the player is excellent while soundtrack falls nothing short of being amazing. To some extent it looks like some degree of inspiration has been drawn from CAVE’s [i]DonPachi[/i] series, particularly in regards to the appearance of the scoring items and some of the enemy designs. It might be nice to have a centralized element of the UI that displays the remaining amount of Break Mode time the player has left at their disposal, rather than having to take one’s eyes away from the action to check a panel positioned on the left side of the screen, and it wouldn’t hurt to have a boss health gauge display that becomes transparent when the player’s ship passes through it either, but both of these are minor issues and don’t do any great harm to the overall presentation.

In short it would be sufficient to say that Crimzon Clover WORLD IGNITION is everything a bullet hell game should be. Highly polished, highly refined and highly enjoyable, it’s exactly the type of game that arcades could have done with several years ago, and is certainly one that those in search of a worthwhile scrolling shooter could do with today. With developers like YOTSUBANE and Adventure Planning Service around, one can rest assured that the future of the genre lies in good hands.

17952885.review:
Crimzon Clover is the Quentin Tarantino of shmups. It is very up front and honest about its influences but manages to take the tropes of a given genre and make it into something fresh and new, which may be the wankiest thing ever said about this game.

Long story short, it's an excellent shooter. Various elements recall the best games from Cave, Raizing, and even Triangle Service without feeling derivative of any of them. Except Cave. The DoDonPachi vibe is strong with this one but the play system is different enough that it's more like a knowing nod to one of the greats than a pure ripoff. 

Graphically the game is a bit hit and miss. Some sprites and backgrounds seem a tad too scaled up and as a result are more pixelated than you'd expect. The background variety is quite good though. Weapon and bullet graphics are excellent. Colorful enough that you never feel cheated, unlike every single game ever made by Raizing/8ing. 

If you like shooters, you need this game. There's nothing here that's groundbreaking but not everything needs to be. This is a game made by a competent developer with an obvious love for the genre in general, and I can not wait to see what Yotsubane will come up with next.

Halfway through the final stage, no continues used, no lives remaining. Sweat pouring from my brow, knuckles white with strain, thumb screaming in agony from the constant pressure. A stream of bullets from every direction. Too many too dodge, too many to bomb... and yet somehow...

"In the end I may remain nothing. Even so will you fighting?" 

The words flash across my screen, a cryptic message from the enemy. Are they mocking me? Or perhaps honoring the determination with which I struggle against the inevitability of my fate? Indeed, in the end I will remain nothing. Even so I struggle on, Crimson Heart's mocking words echoing in my mind as wave after wave of enemies crash down upon me, filling the screen with orbs of blue and red.

Today my best was not enough, but tomorrow is a new day, and the ex-boss awaits. I cannot rest until I know the truth, until I have seen what in the end I may remain. Until then, I will fighting!

17603601.review:
Bullet-hell shooters are like the chocolate chip cookies of gaming: the look the same from the outside, and there's a ton of variety, but a good chocolate chip cookie can bring so much more to the experience if the right amount of love and the right quality of ingredients are blended together. With that said, [b]Crimzon Clover: [i]WORLD IGNITION[/i][/b] is the triple fudge dark chocolate chip cookie made with golden wheat flour, fresh eggs and just a little bit of cayenne pepper to bring out the depth of the chocolate.

I don't delve too far into bullet-hell shooters, but once in a while I absolutely crave these little morsels of gaming, and when the craving takes over I need a good shmup to take me over and [b]Crimzon Clover: [i]WORLD IGNITION[/i][/b] has enough deep mechanics, great style, and hand cramping, pants crapping moments to scratch that itch one-hundred times over and still have me begging for more.

If you're at all interested in [b]Crimzon Clover: [i]WORLD IGNITION[/i][/b], and I assume that if you're on this page that you are, then buy this game! You'll be helping a Japanese indie developer and getting a crazy-fun rollercoaster ride of bullets!

All action, no fluff. This game is all about non-stop bullet hell action and not bogging down your game with story or characters you don't care about.

With 3 ships (and an unlockable 4th) to choose from to find your groove, unlimited continues so you can see the end (even though you'll be dying with every wave of bullets by the end), a lot of achievements, time attacks, and even pro replays to see that it's actually possible to survive without a scratch... there's quite a bit to do for those wanting a fun, challenging, and no-nonsense game.

Thanks to those unlimited continues and being able to see the end, the game's difficulty isn't as frustrating and challenges you to actually try and survive as much as possible (since your stars which affect score are reset with continues and there's an achievment for not continuing and even not dying).
